title: Locatrix
description:
Locatrix tracks a user's location and makes it easy to share, while preserving user privacy and safety by only sharing city-level location. Locatrix comes in two parts: an app which is downloaded to the user's phone and a website which leads the user through configuring their sharing tools.
I was the sole UI/UX designer for the app and website, and contributed to coding.

title: Zombie Rendezvous
description:
Zombie Rendezvous is designed for play in in 30 minutes or less by children ages 4-12. Players receive a paper game booklet when they are infected by a zombie. Through the course of curing their infection, players learn about the difference between bacterial, viral, and fungal infections, how doctors prevent the spread of diseases, how pathologists grow cultures of diseases, and how researchers design drugs.
I designed and illustrated the entire booklet, with the exception of the three cover zombies.

title: Puzzling Madness of John A. Macdonald
description: The Puzzling Madness of John A. Macdonald is a puzzle/scavenger hunt across Downtown Toronto. Designed for the Canada 150 celebration, it features puzzles set in Toronto of 1867, using historical handbills, maps, and sites. I am the art director and designer for the project, photographing and creating ad campaigns, crafting print and physical props, costuming actors, co-supervising auditions and rehearsals, and running game experience tests.

title: Hello, Velo!
description:
Hello, Velo! attaches to a bicycle and allows its owner to communicate with it, for example to determine where she left it parked. A GSM (cellular network) antenna and a GPS antenna attached to a Kinoma Element form the device's functional core, and are enclosed in a custom 3D-printed case.
This project was completed as a demo to showcase the Internet of Things (IOT) capabilities of the Kinoma Element. I crafted the case, electronics, code, and documentation myself.

title: JoyNews
description:
As part of Toronto's 2017 Comedy Hack Day, my partner and I worked with another designer and a comedian to develop a hardware prototype of a system that makes it nicer for people to read the news. Our system integrates real-time javascript-based emotion detection as well as the HTML5 vibration API.
I was the primary visual designer for this project, creating the logo, the layout of the website, as well as the slideshow; I contributed to the shaping of the phone case.

title: Jugger
description: Jugger—a blend of capture the flag, fencing, and rugby—enjoys relative popularity in Germany, but my partner and I introduced the game to the Bay Area and Toronto. I designed our logos and uniforms, along with several giveaways for players and other teams we met at tournaments. I created an Instructable, later featured, to document our building process. My partner and I gave a presentation at Nerd Nite East Bay on the history of the sport, for which I crafted the slides.

title: March for Science Toronto
description: March for Science Toronto was a part of the global March for Science movement. I created the website design for the march, in addition to performing other organizing duties.

title: #resist shop
description: To raise money for nonprofit advocacy organizations in the wake of the 2016 American election, I created 3D models of necklace pendants and cufflinks showcasing pussyhats, uteruses, and other objects.

title: User Interface Design Course
deliverable: assignments, website, lectures, and student projects
description: I instructed an upper division undergraduate course on Human Computer Interaction / User Interface Design and Development in Summer 2015, including redesigning the curriculum, including a studio component in place of half the lectures, and integrating a new technology. In the process of running this class, I helped shepherd student designs of Android Wear-based mobile applications, both UI and UX.

title: Critical Practices
deliverable: 3D printable, laser cuttable, and electronic compositions
description: Critical Practices, a course offered at UC Berkeley, encourages students to consider fabrication and electronics from an artful and community perspective. Throughout the course, I created a variety of fabricated objects, now documented on hackster.io.

title: H2O IQ
description: H2O IQ is a smart watering system with drip irrigation. It includes an in-garden device and a web interface. The device's uses a moisture sensor and a servo to control water flow, as well as a custom on-board microcontroller and XBee radio to update a server's record of its moisture and query for optimal or desired watering settings. I designed the web interface and electronics code.

title: Doc Savage's Intensive Mental Training
description: Doc Savage's Intensive Mental Training is a word game in the crossword style, that focuses its challenge around syllables rather than pure letter counts. At least one foreign language (Spanish) professor has used it in her classroom as a fun challenge to encourage growth in second-language learners. I collaborated on the game design, and created the board and instructions' visual design.

title: Kinoma Create Hoedown!
description: Hoedown is an Austin-themed interactive character generation system that tests a person’s intelligence, constitution, and more, using a series of entertaining challenges; it was developed as a tech/experience demo for the Kinoma Create (an IOT prototyping platform). I was the sole visual and electronics designer, collaborated on game design, and helped showcase this game as a part of Kinoma's booth at South By Southwest 2014.
